title: Nutritional benefits, ethnomedicinal uses, phytochemistry, pharmacological properties and toxicity of Spondias mombin Linn: a comprehensive review
author: Ogunro; Olalekan Bukunmi; Oyeyinka; Barnabas Oluwatomide; Gyebi; Gideon Ampoma; Batiha; Gaber El-Saber
description: AbstractObjectives. Spondias mombin is traditionally used as an herbal medicine for several human diseases and ailments in the tropical regions across the globe
text:
Abstract
Objectives
Spondias mombin is traditionally used as an herbal medicine for several human diseases and ailments in the tropical regions across the globe including the African countries. This study aimed to provide comprehensive information on nutritional benefits, ethnomedicinal uses, phytochemical constituents, pharmacological properties and toxicology study of S. mombin. Information was gathered from documented literatures in scientific database.
Key findings
The study revealed that S. mombin has nutritional values; with the leaf, fruit, flower, seed, and stem bark possessing a wide range of ethnomedicinal uses across several regions, with documented pharmacological properties. S. mombin has a frequent rate of ethnomedicinal utility in cases of abortion, constipation, fever, gonorrhea, postpartum hemorrhage, digestive pain, diarrhoea, dysentery and wounds. Ethnopharmacological studies showed that crude extracts and chemical compounds from S. mombin manifested in vivo and in vitro biological and pharmacological activities. About 102 isolated compounds from the leaf, fruit, or stem bark of S. mombin have been reported.
Summary
Overall, S. mombin has several nutritive and ethnomedicinal benefits owing to its chemical constituents, which are linkable to the several pharmacological activities. There remains however, the need for dosage intake caution, upon the advice of medical professionals.
Introduction
Medicinal plants are herbs or therapeutic agents that are used for curative purposes. Estimates from the World Health Organization (WHO) indicate a dominant 80% of our global population rely on medicinal plants for primary healthcare, because they play a significant role in maintaining human health and improving the state of life.[
[1](javascript:;)]
Medicinal plants can either be utilized straightforwardly as teas, or as agents for the synthesis of pharmaceuticals, just as the organic molecules of active principles in plants are potential templates for synthetic drugs.[
[2](javascript:;)] This has thus attracted focus in the pharmaceutical industries with regard to identifying novel bioactive principles for the treatment of current and unfolding health challenges.
Like some known medicinal plants considered to have multiple economic and ethnomedicinal purposes, Spondias mombin Linn serves in diverse roles such as in herbal medicine, with many ethnopharmacological properties for the management of several ailments implicated in the folkloric uses across cultures. For instance, plant parts such as leaves, flower, fruits, seed, stem bark, pulp and root are ethnomedicinally viable in managing or treating ailments from leprosy, severe cough, diarrhoea, dysentery, dyspepsia, gastralgia, colic, constipation, hemorrhoids, gonorrhea, leucorrhoea, dystocia, to postpartum haemorrhage and inflammation.[
[3](javascript:;)] Various pharmacological properties of the plant have been described; all of which are linkable to the chemical constitution, as well as the nutritional compositions and benefits of several plant parts.
The conventional knowledge of this plant across several cultures is a compendium of information around its utility and value, which are explorable for scientists in the areas of nutritive benefits, phytoconstituents, pharmacological features, as well and toxicological evaluation. This review is therefore aimed at to providing a categorized, up-to-date, and comprehensive botanical information, nutritional benefits, ethnomedicinal and nonmedicinal uses, phytochemistry, pharmacological activities and toxicity of S. mombin. This is with an intent to provide a robust appraisal of its ethnopharmacological values as traditional herbal medicine, identify any ambiguity, while providing a scientific premise for future studies for biochemists, pharmacists, medicinal chemists, pharmacologists and physicians.
Search Strategy
A review of scientific literature was compiled from the scientific database (such as Science Direct, Espacenet Web of Science, SciFinder, Scopus, PubMed, Scielo, Google Scholar, Google Patents, BioMed Central, Medline, Springerlink, Mendeley) and other web sources such as The Plant List (
[http://www.theplantlist.org](http://www.theplantlist.org)), The International Plant Names Index ( [www.ipni.org](http://www.ipni.org)) and Plant Resources of Tropical Africa. Relevant and useful details (in relation to the botany and common names, herbal properties and medicinal uses, phytochemistry as well as the biological and pharmacological activities of S. mombin) were also collated from published books, thesis, conference proceedings, abstracts, nonimpact and nonindexed journals. Other articles were also identified by citation tracking from other publications, or by direct access to journal webpages. Keywords used for the identification of useful data are the different scientific names, synonyms, local names and specific terms like S. mombin, ethnomedicine, Spondias lutea, Anacardiaceae, Spondias aurantiaca, medicinal uses, Spondias axillaris, ethnopharmacology, Spondias cytherea, medicinal plants, Spondias dubia, Spondias graveolens, biological activities, phytochemistry, and economic value, for articles published between 1950 and 2022. Literature search was English language-based, except in a few cases of Portuguese and was translated to the English language.
Results
Origin, botany and morphology of Spondias mombin
Spondias mombin is a stringently tropical plant widely found in the rainforest lowlands but has adapted to grow in more arid zones. The deciduous fruit tree is widely distributed in Nigeria (especially in the Southwestern regions), Ivory Coast, Brazil, Bolivia, Mexico, Peru, Venezuela, Colombia, Guianas, as well as a number of global tropical forests in the world.[
[4](javascript:;), [5](javascript:;)] An evidence-based analysis and evaluation of African origin in comparison to the American region clarified that S. mombin can be dispersed naturally against the previous opinions that the plant was introduced to Africa.[ [6](javascript:;)]
Spondias mombin (Linn) is of the Sapindales order and genus Spondias. It is essentially a member of family Anacardiaceae, comprising about 73 genera, 850 species. It is often referred to as Hog plum in the English-speaking tropical regions.
[Table 1](javascript:;) shows a list of countries and localities and their various local names for the tree and fruits of S. mombin.

The tropical tree (
[plate 1](javascript:;)) grows erectly (coated by a thick and rough bark) as tall as 20–30 m with a trunk between 60 and 75 cm in diameter.[ [7](javascript:;)] The leaves are 20–45 cm in length, hairy underneath, and with 5–11 pairs of petiolate leaflets and short petioles, while the flowers from the tree are usually white, and are produced abundant in small and fragrant panicles.[ [7](javascript:;)] The stomata of the leaf which are tetracytic/anomocytic spread out on the dorsal or abaxial surface; the midrib has a bulging symmetry with supportive vascular bundles in a closed arc structure.[ [7](javascript:;)] The fruits are 3–4 cm in length, and 2.5 cm in width, with a tough, but thin skin, and a juicy pulp. These fruits are usually green on the onset and then become golden-yellow when they are ripe depending to the carotenoid composition. The seeds which are significantly big and rough are in the endocarp, which is a pentagonal structure covered with tubercles. As the most distinctive fruit component, the endocarp owes this to the parenchymatous and the locular mass.[ [4](javascript:;)] Adhering to the internal surface of the tegument is the endosperm, due to its thin and starchy nature.
Plate 1:
Spondias mombin tree (plant).
In a study on S. mombin tree morphology, normal morphology was reported to include 52.8% with four loculi, 44.8% with one-seeded endocarp, and 15.2% without seed formation.[
[9](javascript:;)] Due to its hard seed coat, S. mombin seeds exhibit physical innate dormancy. Sandpaper scarification at the distal ends and micropyle of S. mombin seeds has been reported to be the best pre-germination treatment.[ [10](javascript:;)] The physical and chemical characterization of the mature fruits from 14 adult plants of S. mombin revealed the range and average for the following characters: 5.7–16.5g, 9.9 g fruit weight; 29.5–39.8 mm, 33.7 mm fruit length; 18.3–26.8 mm, 23.5 mm fruit diameter, and 69.7–77.5%, 72.6% pulp yield.[ [11](javascript:;)] Physical and physicochemical quality of the fruits may vary from one region to the other. For instance, differences were identified in the physical and physicochemical quality of the fruits in the two regions of Boa Vista, Roraima in a study on the biometric characterization of fruits and physicochemical characteristics of pulps of S. mombin.[ [12](javascript:;)]
In addition, the °brix acidity ratio is known to increase with advancement in maturity, such that half of the ripe fruits have higher reducing sugar levels, compared to the mature green fruits.[
[13](javascript:;)] Meanwhile, the mature green fruits are climacteric and are known to have increase in CO2 and decrease in O2 concentration when stored in closed confines.[ [14](javascript:;)] Upon studying the growth rate, the fruits were observed to increase steadily and rapidly, until 60 days post-anthesis, after which growth rate declined gradually until 90 days post-florescence.[ [15](javascript:;)] Notably too, maturation did not commence until after 100 days, with ripening taking place approximately 117 days post-anthesis.[ [15](javascript:;)]
Nutritional compositions and benefits of Spondias mombin
Fruit pulp consumption has been recommended for the nutritive value, fibre, ascorbic acid, and carotenoid content, because of the demonstrated antioxidant capacity (phenolic compounds), in form of free radical scavenging, and modulatory effects against the onset, development or degenerative pathophysiology of chronic diseases.[
[16](javascript:;)] Like most tropical fruits, S. mombin fruits are tropical and present exotic taste and aroma as well as good nutritional value. The nutritional value such as rich mineral and vitamin constituents, high and low moisture, and lipid levels respectively, is characterized by low pH and reducing sugars. It is also a source of carotenoids and phenolics compounds. The fruits from S. mombin are characteristically distinct with high amounts of vitamin A and carotenoids in their epicarp.[ [17](javascript:;)] While investigating the nutritional values of S. mombin fruits, more light has been shed on the soluble solid, vitamin C, and mineral contents, as well as pH and titratable acidity.[ [18](javascript:;)]
Spondias mombin fruits are usually consumed fresh or processed and are generally accepted for their unique sour to sour-sweet taste.[
[19](javascript:;)] The physicochemical characteristics of the fruit pulp is not affected by thermal treatment, with the fruit processing reported to have no depleting effect on antioxidant capacity.[ [20](javascript:;)] Furthermore, the development of mixed beverages made of S. mombin fruit and cashew apple with the addition of Fructooligosaccharides (FOS), was acceptable as regular sucrose drink for healthy, nutritious, and tasty foods.[ [21](javascript:;)]In vivo reports show that the juice effects and mechanisms on health status is notably related to phytonutrients like vitamins and minerals, in the improvement of health, disease cure and prevention.[ [21](javascript:;), [22](javascript:;)]
The nutritional composition of the sorghum stem sheath-S. mombin extract, upon evaluation, showed observable increase in proximal, ascorbic acid and mineral constituents from the addition of 5% S. mombin extract to the drinks from the sheath of sorghum stem.[
[23](javascript:;)] The study indicated that sorghum stem sheath and extract from S. mombin could be used to make nutritive drinks at ambient temperature, with safe antinutritive levels.
Studies have provided insights on the use of the pulp extract in jam, juice, and ice cream production, but not on the micronutrient potentials of these fruit pulps.[
[24–28](javascript:;)] The proximate analyses of S. mombin fruit pulps have reported and recommended the pulps as fruit snacks for the obese and diabetics because of the distinct moisture content, crude protein, crude lipid, crude fibre, total carbohydrate as well as the sodium, magnesium, and potassium values.[ [29](javascript:;)]
Feeding experiments investigated the direct effect of the hydrocyanic acid (HCN) contents of S. mombin leaves on the performance and digestibility in goats and was reported that nitrogen balance and nitrogen digestibility were depressed by the 41.1 mg/kg HCN content in the plant.[
[30](javascript:;)] While hydrocyanic acid negatively affected urinary nitrogen, it influenced dry matter and energy intake. The study also reported nitrogen, crude fibre, and iron in the S. mombin leaf.
The nontoxic effect of S. mombin leaf meal on blood indices of broilers has been reported, thus, indicating its potential incorporation (15% content) in the finished ration of broilers.[
[31](javascript:;)] The study also reported the proximate composition of S. mombin leaf meal as moisture, ether extracts, ash, crude protein, crude fibre, nitrogen free extract and metabolizable energy. Similarly, in an earlier report, nutritive factors such as total carbohydrate (68.92%), crude protein (11.04%), moisture (15.13%), crude fibre (10.51%), and a good level of crude fat (4.82%) were reported in S. mombin leaf.[ [32](javascript:;)]
Spondias mombin leaves have been screened for constituents such as ascorbic acid (18.75 mg/100 g), riboflavin (0.35 mg/100 g), thiamine (0.06 mg/100 g), and niacin (2.75 mg/100 g), as well as potassium (2.66%), manganese (0.455%), sodium (0.100%), calcium (1.410%) and phosphorous (0.300%).[
[33](javascript:;)]
In another report, the use of S. mombin as a potential origin of valuable animal product formulation and feed stuff has been advocated, on the back of analytical results showing that the leaves contain thiamine (0.05 mg/100g), ascorbic acid (19.35 mg/100 g), riboflavin (0.25 mg/100 g), and niacin (3.75 mg/100 g), as well as potassium (2.55%), manganese (0.3045%), sodium (0.100%), calcium (1.310%) and phosphorous (0.200%).[
[34](javascript:;)] In the same vein, S. mombin pulp contains a good amount (mg/100 g) of sodium (5.551), magnesium (15.095), phosphorous (32.849), potassium (288.276), calcium (11.038), as well as manganese (0.025), iron (0.327), copper (0.118), aluminum (0.394), and barium (0.069).[ [34](javascript:;)] Furthermore, 100 g of S. mombin pulp can supply up to 37% of recommended daily allowance (RDA) for vitamin A.[ [35](javascript:;)] Moreso, the seed kernel was demonstrated as a valuable source of nutritious food, with haematinic and anti-diabetic potentials because it contains carbohydrate, ash, crude fibre, moisture, crude protein, crude fat, calcium, iron, magnesium, manganese, zinc and copper (40.56%, 8.09%, 31.86%, 8.48%, 7.73%, 3.28%, 1317 mg/kg, 839.08 mg/kg, 494.71 mg/kg, 17.93 mg/kg, 15.27 mg/kg and 7.68 mg/kg, respectively).[ [36](javascript:;)] Similarly, the leaf of S. mombin has been recommended as a good haematinic and antidiabetic agent, owing to the high contents of iron and chromium.[ [37](javascript:;)] Results from this study revealed elemental constituents in the leaf such as iron, zinc, manganese, chromium, copper, cadmium, potassium, calcium, phosphorous and sodium in the respective proportions of 574.00 mg/kg, 9.60 mg/kg, 23.00 mg/kg, 66.00 mg/kg, 13.00 mg/kg, 50.00 mg/kg, 1.20%, 1.05%, 0.32% and 1.80%.[ [36](javascript:;)] The proximate analysis of the leaf, stem and root also affirmed nutritional properties. The findings revealed that the root and leaf with 35.78% and 32.59% respectively were rich in moisture. The leaf also with 32.08% was the richest in carbohydrate while the stem was richest in ash having a proportion of 4.52%. Each of the root, stem or leaf are rich in vitamins B1 and C in proportions above 2 mg/100 ml and 1 mg/100 ml respectively. Similarly, the leaf and stem have rich mineral contents especially for potassium and sodium.[ [38](javascript:;)]
The acceptability of fruit-based beverages from S. mombin has reported to be linked to nutritional characteristics such as the notable ascorbic acid content, reducing sugar content, titratable acidity contents, total soluble solid content, and pH in both the pulps and formulations.[
[39](javascript:;)] In a previous study, six carotenoids (lutein, β-cryptoxanthin, α- and β-carotene, zeinoxanthin, and zeaxanthin) were identified in the pulp of S. mombin.[ [40](javascript:;)]
The physico-chemical parameters (colour, titratable acidity, pH, total soluble solids, and moisture and lipid contents), examined in the S. mombin fruit pulp, revealed appreciable levels of bioactive compounds (ascorbic acid and total phenolics).[
[41](javascript:;)] The characteristics of the foam dried at 60 °C (recommended to maintain the best characteristics of the fresh pulp) indicated preserved quality of S. mombin pulp with respect to titratable acidity, pH and colour.[ [18](javascript:;)] The macronutrient composition of S. mombin pulp is 8.72 g/100 g of carbohydrate, 0.87 g/100 g of protein, 1.51 g/100g of lipids, 0.70 g/100 g of ashes and 88.2% of moisture.[ [42](javascript:;)]
Characterization study of S. mombin fruits and their pulps revealed that the fruit has variable dimensions, weighing between 1.35 and 16.47 g, and averaging 7.19 g; while the pulp was considered acidic with pH of 2.53, total titratable acidity of 1.86%, total sugar contents of 4.54.100 g–1 as well as with contents of tannins (299.81 mg/100 g) and carotenoids (28.30 µg/g) [
[43](javascript:;)] Another characterization study of fruits from 17 S. mombin matrices for pulp yield, size, moisture, soluble solids, pH, titratable acidity ratio, vitamin C, and total carotenoids revealed three great fruit matrices (above 15 g); four medium type (12–15 g) and the majority (10 matrices) presented small fruits (less than 12 g), and that S. mombin is not a source of ascorbic acid for food, on the evidence of low levels.[ [44](javascript:;)]
In the work of Akharaiyi et al.,[
[45](javascript:;)] fruit juice from harvested S. mombin yielded protein (6.03%), fat (1.85%), pH (3.63%), fibre (0.64%), moisture (80.60%), ash (0.54%), carbohydrate (11.61%) and titratable acidity (28.52) proximal compositions. Meanwhile, the elemental constituents were potassium (276.2 mg/100 g), manganese (1.15 mg/100 g), copper (0.121 mg/100 g), sodium (4.45 mg/100 g), zinc (136.42 mg/100 g), magnesium (12.36 mg/100 g), lead (0.01 mg/100 g), phosphorus (28.22 mg/100 g), calcium (13.04 mg/100 g) and iron (0.48 mg/100 g).[ [45](javascript:;)]
Evaluation of changes in pectinmethylesterase (PME) and peroxidase (POD) activities for the conventional industrial processing of tropical juices from fruit pulping, homogenization and pasteurization in Brazil, revealed that both enzymes showed substantial loss of activity in the course of processing, with the final product indicating a 25% and 2.5% residual activity for PME and POD respectively.[
[20](javascript:;)] In S. mombin juice, PME was more thermal resistant than POD, while the carotenoid content was unaffected by processing.[ [20](javascript:;)] Furthermore, of concentration and temperature can afferct thermophysical features such as thermal conductivity, density, thermal diffusivity and apparent viscosity of S. mombin within the range of 7.8–49.4 ◦Brix and 0 –77.1 ºC, which suggest their importance to avoid under-processing or an incorrect calculation of equipment dimensions.[ [46](javascript:;)]
Saccharification by extracts of cellulolytic enzyme, derived from S. mombin fruit residue cultured Penicillium roqueforti ATCC 10110, indicated that Mn2+ added enzyme as another frugal and promising process, when compared to the processes that utilize pure enzymes, and thus require pre-treatment stages for the saccharification of residue.[
[47](javascript:;)] Meanwhile, the seed residues of S. mombin can serve a great deal bio-products availability in industrial uses of crude extracts that contains cellulolytic enzymes by promoting the valorization of the residues.[ [48](javascript:;)]
In another study to make S. mombin flavor-frozen yogurt from goat milk, and to evaluate its sensory acceptance, it was shown that the use of 30% pulp constitution in goat milk frozen yoghurt, because of the improved sensory characteristics was well accepted as an alternative in the food industry.[
[49](javascript:;)]. Microbiological qualities such as thermotolerant coliforms bacteria counts, and standard plate for Salmonella, Staphylococcus aureus, psychrotrophs, and lactic acid bacteria counts were taken into consideration.[ [49](javascript:;)] The microscopic evaluation of 45 samples of the fruits of S. mombin collected in Brazil showed that 86.36% of the samples contained dirtiness, mainly from the scraps of insects which indicated that no one of the samples was in line with the established quality standards for tropical fruit juices ─ Quality and Identity Standards (QIS).[ [50](javascript:;)] Similarly, the quality of frozen fruit pulps S. mombin from Paraíba and Pernambuco States in Brazil revealed that revealed that 68.2% S. mombin pulp samples did not correlate with the QIS juice of the fruits by considering the pH, soluble solids, acidity in citric acid, reducing sugars and ascorbic acid.[ [51](javascript:;)]
Fruit pulp from S. mombin concentrated to 90% saturation level, and evaluated for modulatory action against the bovine trypsin, porcine pancreatic α-amylase, and human salivary α-amylase, revealed the inhibitory capacity of pancreatic α-amylase.[
[52](javascript:;)] This suggests the medicinal use of these inhibitors as agents against some mammalian digestive enzymes that reduce the absorption of starch, which may alter carbohydrate digestion in obese or diabetic patients.[ [4](javascript:;)]
Because of seasonal variations in the concentration of minerals that may occur in S. mombin, it was suggested that the formulation and/or supplementation rations for ruminants should have considerations for both the amount of minerals in legumes and biological accessibility of the minerals.[
[53](javascript:;)] An investigation employing microwave-assisted alkaline treatment (MAAT) in the characterization of S. mombin bagasse revealed that MAAT significantly indicated varied influence on proximal composition (hemicellulose, lignin component, reduced crude fibre, increased cellulose content), thus affirming that the technical feasibility of the potential utility of bagasse after MAAT, for food application.[ [54](javascript:;)]
The trade of S. mombin thrives on the need to provide alternative means to healthy living through local or unorthodox pharmacognosy.[
[55](javascript:;)] The root is often used as an emergency water source, while the stem serves as fences in farmlands, and shelter by artisans.[ [56](javascript:;)]S. mombin wood is used in the production of match sticks and boxes, pencils, and penholder, spatulas, interior overlay of homes and boats, and as an alternative for cork. Brazilians make seal wax with it and use it as bottle stoppers.
In most parts of Africa, ashes from the wood is used as indigo-dye, while gum is employed as glue or adhesives.[
[57](javascript:;)] Throughout the Amazon region, S. mombin fruit is primarily used in the production of wine traded as Vinho de Taperiba, while the fruit is made into a cider-like drink in Guatemala.[ [56](javascript:;)] The flowers can serve decorative purposes, while the nectar is worked on intensively by honeybees.[ [57](javascript:;)]
In most African countries, young S. mombin trees offer utility as poles in hut making, while the branches are often used as garden poles, as well as in making handles for axes and hoes. The use of the wood as a major source fuel or firewood is common among the people in Costa Rica and Puerto Rico.[
[56](javascript:;)]Spondias mombin serves as an efficient fuel in a simple, frugal, and environmental-friendly method developed to synthesize Zinc oxide nanoparticles (ZnO NPs).[ [58](javascript:;)]
Ethnomedicinal uses of Spondias mombin
Spondias mombin is widely used as herbal remedies for diverse ailments or conditions. Interestingly, nearly every part of the tree ranging from its fruit, leaves, seeds, stem bark, bark, to even flowers, has specific attributed properties of medicinal importance (
[Table 2](javascript:;)) in several regions of the world like Nigeria, Cuba, Peru, Mexico, Bolivia, Nicaragua, Brazil, Guianas, Belize, Venezuela, Haiti, Trinidad and Colombia.

In Nigeria, and other parts of the globe, S. mombin leaf is widely employed as treatments for reproductive tract infections. In fact, it is commonly used to induce pregnancy, minimize intrapartum and post-partum bleeding and, to get mammary milk production, as well as a vaginal wash product, to treat post-partum uterine or vaginal infections, among midwives.
In several African regions, either the bark, leaf, or a combination of both are potent remedies for cough, fever, constipation, yaws, sore throat, gonorrhea, cholera and gastric problems, as well as an intra-partum aid.[
[101](javascript:;)]
The poultice or leaf decoction serves as an antiseptic vaginal wash, and as a contraceptive in Peru.[
[82](javascript:;), [116](javascript:;)] In Belize, S. mombin leaf decoction is used in treating dysentery and diarrhoea ( [Table 2](javascript:;)). The medicinal capacities and socio-economic relevance of S. mombin have also been reported.[ [123](javascript:;)]
The leaf of S. mombin are considered antiseptic, with broad antimicrobial spectrum, utilised in ameliorating various microbial infections (virus, fungi, bacteria, yeast and candida). They are externally applied in the treatment of infected cuts, rashes and burns (
[Table 2](javascript:;)).
There has been reported claims of the local use of the leaf for memory enhancement in South-western Nigeria.[
[103](javascript:;), [104](javascript:;)] Similarly, the leaf, when chewed with Kola acuminate fruit is also acclaimed to have memory enhancement properties, as substantiated in a few studies.[ [105](javascript:;), [106](javascript:;)]
The bark of the S. mombin tree is usually used in treating arthritis, rheumatism, muscle pain, injuries, and inflammation; and it is considered analgesic.[
[3](javascript:;), [61](javascript:;), [62](javascript:;)]
Spondias mombin bark has rich astringent tannin constituent, and the decoctions are its form of use in cases of diarrhoea and dysentery, blennorrhagia, haemorrhoids, internal and external bleeding wounds.[
[3](javascript:;), [116](javascript:;)] In addition, the bark is used in treating inflammation of tonsillitis, laryngitis, intestine, skin, and mucous membranes; it is often used to treat malaria, fever, snakebite, bladder and kidney stones.[ [64](javascript:;), [84](javascript:;), [116](javascript:;)] The bark, being an efficacious local antiseptic, is used as a cicatrizant and healing remedy wounds, rashes, dermatitis, leishmaniosis, psoriasis, leprosy and other skin problems.[ [62](javascript:;)] Furthermore, the bark of the tree is predominantly used as contraceptive and abortifacient, as well as for cancers of the ovarian and uterine region.[ [70](javascript:;), [94](javascript:;)] ( [Table 2](javascript:;)).
The several, small, fragrant flowers of S. mombin are functional in herbal medicine. The infusion of the flowers treats sore throat, laryngitis, mouth sores, eye infections and cataracts.[
[61](javascript:;), [110](javascript:;)] A tea of the flowers and leaves also relieves urethritis, stomachache, biliousness and cystitis as well as inflammation of both eyes and throat.[ [60](javascript:;)]
The fruit is usually consumed in form of mild laxative and can induce vomiting when consumed in large quantities. The gum is equally a valuable expectorant and tapeworm expellant.[
[124](javascript:;), [125](javascript:;)]
Phytochemistry of Spondias mombin
Phytochemicals are natural principles or bioactive constituents that are present in plants.[
[126–128](javascript:;)] Such natural compounds function with nutrients and dietary agents to protect animals and humans from diseases.[ [129](javascript:;)] Extraction and characterization of several active phytochemicals (including secondary metabolites, amino acids and mineral elements) from green plants have led to the production of some high activity profile drugs.[ [129](javascript:;)] The medicinal attributes of botanicals are in their bioactive phytochemical ingredients, which show various physiological effects in humans.[ [130](javascript:;)]
Various chemical constituents such as phenols, tannins, anthraquinones, flavonoids, caffeoyl ester, alkaloids, saponins, 6-alkenylsalcyclic acids, and proanthocyanins, have been isolated from S. mombin, and are mostly attributable to their extract bioactivities (
[Table 3](javascript:;)– [5](javascript:;)). The chemistry of this plant has been reported and these bioactive principles have been implicated in several pharmacological activities.[ [73](javascript:;)]

The associated link between the compositions of S. mombin plant and their reported ethnomedicinal uses has prompted several types of research on its phytochemistry. For instance, in separate works, a new steroid, estra-17-propoxy, 3’, 4’-dimethoxy–3yl benzoate (
[Table 3](javascript:;)) and a steroidal glucoside, 16-0-(3’,4’, 5’-trimethoxybenzoyl) -3-0-β-D-diglucopyranosyl cholest-15-ene have been isolated from the leaf of S. mombin[ [131](javascript:;), [132](javascript:;)] ( [Table 3](javascript:;)). This thus suggests that S. mombin can be used as a remedy in asthma and bronchitis treatment, hormone and bile regulation, birth control and lactation stimulation.[ [131](javascript:;)] Furthermore, there also lies the attendant anti-inflammatory, oxytocic, bronchodilator-anti-asthmatic, and antioxidant properties. Another report showed that 3β-olean-12-en-3-yl (9Z)-hexadec-9-enoate (an α-amylase inhibitor) was isolated from S. mombin leaf.[ [133](javascript:;)]
A phytoconstituent compendium of the volatile oil of S. mombin pulp or juice has been detailed, two of which were classified as hydrocarbons (2-heptane, ocimene), and esters (ethyl benzoate, methyl benzoate, ethyl cinnamate, ethyl octanoate), with 1-methyl-1-ethoxyethane and 1,1-Diethoxyethane being classified as miscellaneous.[
[150](javascript:;)] ( [Table 4](javascript:;)). The study noted that not just a single compound was responsible for the traditional fruit aroma, but rather, a synergistic contribution of compounds.[ [150](javascript:;)] The characterized volatiles from the S. mombin fruit recorded a total of 46 and 28 volatiles, present in the free and glycosidically bound fractions, respectively.[ [148](javascript:;)] Flavonol 3-O-glycosides in S. mombin leaf were recently reported.[ [161](javascript:;)] Meanwhile, 48 compounds were identified in the volatile fraction of S. mombin fruit, based on Gas chromatography (GC) and Gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC–MS) analyses, which made up 82% of the volatile oils.[ [151](javascript:;)] The major components reported in this study were ethyl acetate, ethyl butyrate, ethyl hexanoate, hexyl butyrate and linalool (14.4%, 14.4%, 8.8%, 7.9% and 6.1%, respectively). Interestingly, the ester and linalool constituents were reported to be responsible for the fruit aroma ( [Table 3](javascript:;)).
In another study, S. mombin fruits analysed by GC and GC–MS were reported to have a total of 261 compounds, made up of 32 hydrocarbons (4.1%), three sulfur compounds (trace), 56.2% of the 126 esters, 10.4% of eight lactones, 3.2% of the 22 carbonyl compounds, 19.5% were the 16 acids, 5.5% of the 37 alcohols and ethers, while the remaining 1.1% made up the 17 unclassified compounds.[
[149](javascript:;)] The major volatile products identified in the study were γ-hexalactone, 2(5H)-furanone, methyl hexadecanoate and ethyl 3-hydroxyhexanoate.[ [149](javascript:;)]
In an earlier work, 26 volatile principles had been identified, comprising majorly of terpenes and their derivatives, with the compounds implicated significantly in contributing to fruit aroma.[
[133](javascript:;)] These compounds are: β-caryophyllene, cis-β-ocimene, trans-ocimene, α-caryophyllene and delta-limonene.[ [162](javascript:;)] Other volatile principles with unique flavor include: β-selinene, 1, 2, 3, 4, 4a, 5, 6, 8a-octahydro-4a, 8-dimethyl naphthalene, and 1, 3-cyclohexadien-1, 5, 5, 6-tetramethyl-1, 3- cyclo-hexadiene.[ [147](javascript:;)]
The examination and evaluation of volatile oil constituents from fresh and dried S. mombin leaves, harvested in North-central Nigeria revealed 41 compounds that are majorly classes of monoterpenoids, sesquiterpenoids and non-terpenoids.[
[153](javascript:;)] β-caryophellene and γ-cadinene (in the range of 27.9–30.9% and 9.7–12.3% respectively), were the principal components in both fractions. Meanwhile, the dried leaves had increased oxygenated monoterpenoid contents with decreased sesquiterpenoids hydrocarbons.[ [145](javascript:;)]
The essential oil constituents of S. mombin leaf was reported to be dominated by β-caryophyllene (19.99%).[
[153](javascript:;)] Other major compounds including α-humulene, δ-cadinene, ℘-muurolene, α-gurjunene, 5-isocedranol, α-muurolene, and ℘-cadinene, occurred in respective manner (6.67%, 9.07%, 5.45%, 4.27%, 3.03%, 3.38%, and 3.03%), in the essential oil of the leaf.[ [153](javascript:;)] Notably, there were new detailed reports of 46 compounds in the essential oil of S. mombin leaf.[ [163](javascript:;)] On the other hand, the analysis of the stem bark essential oil of S. mombin, in an earlier report identified sesquiterpenes, which include α-copaene (27.1%), δ-cadinene (11.9%), α-selinene (9.4%) and caryophyllene oxide (8.8%).[ [157](javascript:;)] It has also been reported that the oil of S. mombin leaf was rich in beta-caryophyllene and 3-hexenol [ [137](javascript:;)] ( [Table 3](javascript:;)).
Recently, it was reported that essential oil obtained from S. mombin leaves and fruits, presented yields of 0.03% and 0.002% respectively, with the identification of 28 compounds.[
[140](javascript:;)] Phytol (11.10%), caryophyllene (9.21%), δ-cadiene (5.99%), α-humulene (5.25%), α-cadinol (3.51%) and α-copaene (2.84%) were present in the leaf’s oil, while the fruit’s oil contained β-caryophyllene (26.17%), α-humulene (14.65%), (E,E)-α-farnesene (12.13%), α-terpineol (11.24%), α-copaene (4.53%), palustrol (4.30%), δ-amorphene (3.97%) and α-selinene (2.06%).[ [140](javascript:;)] β-Caryophyllene, often described as a key constituent in S. mombin leaves and fruits[ [153](javascript:;)] was not characterized in the study. Diterpene phytol, the major component in the leaves, was characterized and reported to be biorelevant with regards to its notable antinociceptive and anti-inflammatory activities.[ [140](javascript:;)] It is thus indicative to note that essential oil from S. mombin leaf, generally has a potential frontier role in further biological studies, with the implication of its significant phytol constitution.
More reports indicated the components in S. mombin leaf essential oil as 4-hydroxy-4-methyl-2-pentanone (6.41%), ethyl acetate (0.70%), β-caryophyllene (1.24%), 2,4,10,15 tetrametilheptadecano (1.41%), octadecane (43.51%), tetracosane (8.62%), heptacosane (21.98%) and hexa-triacontane (15.37%).[
[134](javascript:;)] Furthermore, ethyl 3-methylbutanoate, ethyl butanoate, ethyl hexanoate, ethyl 2-methylbutanoate, 3-methylbutyl acetate were responsible for the aroma in fruit pulp of Spondias mombin; methyl 3-hydroxybutanoate in combination with sweet, caramel-like smelling 4-hydroxy-2,5-dimethylfuran-3(2H)-one were responsible for sweet and fruity aroma of the fruit pulp, whereas α-pinene, myrcene and (Z)-β-ocimene are responsible for the turpentine-like aroma note.[ [164](javascript:;)]
The evaluation of volatile compounds in Caja´ and Tapereba´ (S. mombin), from different geographical sources revealed that solid phase microextraction yielded 47 in Caja´ and 48 in Tapereba´, of which (E)-Caryophyllene (18.7%), ethyl butyrate (10.0%), and ethyl hexanoate (7.0%) were major constituents in Tapereba´, while β-phellandrene and myrcene (8.5% and 41.1% respectively), were mostly abundant in the essential oil of Caja´.[
[165](javascript:;)]
Simultaneous distillation and extraction (SDE) identified 46 substances in the Tapereba´ extract and 42 substances in extract of Caja´ out of which (Z)-caryophyllene and limonene (13.2% and 9.5%, respectively) were predominant in the Tapereba´ extract, while myrcene and ρ-cymene (38.0% and 6.2%, respectively) were major components in Caja´ extract[
[43](javascript:;), [146](javascript:;)] ( [Table 3](javascript:;)).
Ellagic and chlorogenic acids in the hydro-ethanol extract of S. mombin leaf were reported to inhibit the migration of leukocytes to the inflammation site[
[166](javascript:;)] which possibly explains the common use of leaves for different types of pain. In addition to having salicylic acid derivatives (including aspirin), the bark and leaves also contain caryophyllene (a well-known chemical with pain-relieving actions) as well as triterpenes and steroids, mono and sesquiterpenes, hydrolysable tannins, phenylpropanoid glycosides, flavonoids and cinnamic derivatives were the phytochemical constituents of the of S. mombin.[ [7](javascript:;)] Coumaroyl, quercetin and gallic acid were also isolated from fractionated extracts of S. mombin, while 2-0-caffeoyl-(+)-allohyroycritic acid and chlorogenic were earlier isolated as caffeoyl esters and a butyl ester.[ [136](javascript:;), [167](javascript:;)] These compounds have antiviral similarities with the phenolic acid, i.e., the long-chain compound, and the two ellagitannins (geraniin and galloygeraniin), as earlier isolated.[ [143](javascript:;), [168](javascript:;)]
Again, 6-alkenylsalcylic acid (a phenolic and pelandjuaic acids active against Biomphalaria glabrats that causes schistosomiasis) was isolated from the ethanolic extract of S. mombin leaf using the chromatographic methods,[
[138](javascript:;)] while a novel β-lactamase inhibitor was also isolated from S. mombin.[ [139](javascript:;)]
Stigmasta-9-ene-3,6,7-triol and 3-hydroxy-22 epoxystigmastane were identified as antimycobacterial phytosterols from the methanolic extract of S. mombin stem bark, via spectroscopic analysis.[
[169](javascript:;)] This was after an earlier report that the stem bark has an abundant constitution of cardiac glycosides, tannins, anthraquinones and flavonoids.[ [170](javascript:;)] Four new compounds were further isolated- mombinrin, mombincone, mombinoate, and mombinol from the stem of S. mombin[ [159](javascript:;)] ( [Table 3](javascript:;)).
Furthermore, epicatechin, epigallocatechin, and stigmasterol phytosterol were isolated from ethyl acetate extract of S. mombin stem bark.[
[171](javascript:;)] Meanwhile, aqueous and crude ethyl acetate extracts of the leaf stem and bark contained terephthalic dodecyl 2-ethylhexyl ester and aspidofractinine-3-methanol were also isolated from the ethyl acetate extract of S. mombin.[ [172](javascript:;)] In addition, aspidofractinine-3-methanol, 9-(2’,2’-Dimethylpropanoilhydrazono)-3,6-dichloro-2,7-bis-[2-(diethylamino)-ethoxy] fluorine, 2-ethylhexyl tetradecyl ester, terephthalic acid, dodecyl 2-ethylhexyl ester di (2-propylpentyl) ester, and phthalic acid were isolated from S. mombin.[ [158](javascript:;)] Mombintane I and II were isolated from S. mombin leaf.[ [173](javascript:;)]
In Brazil, endophytic fungi were isolated from leaf blades (822 isolates) and rachis (690 isolates) of S. mombin. Guignardia sp., Colletotrichum gloeosporioides and Phomopsis sp. were the only recovered from the rachis of the 13 taxa isolated from the two sites examined[
[124](javascript:;)] ( [Table 3](javascript:;)).
Recently, with the application of standard methods, the presence of bioactive compounds such as alkaloids (18.32%), flavonoids (12.84%), saponins (4.80%), tannins (1.24 mg/100 ml), and phenol (0.53 mg/100 ml) were reported in the leaf, while the fruit contained saponins (4.80%), alkaloids (9.0%), flavonoids (2.84%), tannins (1.24 mg/100 ml) and phenol (0.08 mg/100 ml).[
[33](javascript:;)] Similarly, S. mombin leaf was screened and quantified, to demonstrate the presence of bioactive compounds such as saponins, tannins, flavonoids, phenols, and alkaloids, in varying proportions (7.60%, 3.82%, 3.00%, 1.00% and 6.00% respectively).[ [34](javascript:;)] In addition, varying proportions of alkaloids, glycosides, saponins, lipid and oil, tannins, flavonoids, terpenoids and acids in the leaf and bark of S. mombin were reported,[ [174](javascript:;)] while the fruit was revealed to contain esters, alcohols, terpenoids and carbonyl compounds.[ [165](javascript:;)]
Spondias mombin leaf was reported to contain alkaloids, saponins and proanthocyanins, while gum from the tree contains arabinose, water-soluble rhamnose and mannsone.[
[175](javascript:;), [176](javascript:;)]
The extract of S. mombin bark was found to contain polyphenols (34.60%) and flavonoids (0.2536%) in an analytical report.[
[34](javascript:;), [160](javascript:;)] Phytochemical analyses of S. mombin seed kernel indicated the presence of tannins and phytate quantified as 0.06% and 0.0022% respectively,[ [36](javascript:;)] while the leaf revealed the presence of reducing sugars, alkaloids, cardiac glycosides, tannins, flavonoids, steroids, terpenoids and saponins.[ [177](javascript:;)] The major compounds identified in S. mombin seeds were tetradecanoic acid, dodecanoic acid, n-hexadecanoic acid, dihydrocapsaicin, and phenol amides capsaicin present in percentages (17.95%, 22.48%, 15.35%, 5.23% and 12.11%) respectively.[ [135](javascript:;)] Other compounds present in minute quantity in S. mombin seed include4-H-pyran-4-one, (9Z, 12Z)-9,12-octadecadienoic acid (linoleic acid), hexadecanoic acid-methyl ester, and 2.3-dihydro-3.5-dihydroxy-6-methyl, and they have been reported to have antioxidant activity.[ [152](javascript:;)]
The HPLC instrumentation (analysis) was used to elucidate carotenoids [phytofluene, phytoene, all-trans-β-carotene, 9-cis-β-carotene, α-carotene, 13-cis-β-carotene, β-cryptoxanthin (cis and trans), lutein, and zeinoxanthin], in S. mombin pulps.[
[178](javascript:;)] Similarly, five carotenoids (lutein, β-cryptoxanthin, α- and β-carotene, zeinoxanthin) were present in S. mombin pulp, thus accounting for the high pro-vitamin A activity therein.[ [35](javascript:;)]
The GC–MS analysis of S. mombin leaf extract revealed 25 compounds in the ethanolic extract and 29 compounds in the n-hexane extract whereas, both extracts had 10 compounds in common [Phytol, n-Hexadecanoic acids, Phenol 3-methyl-Diisooctyl phthalate, Phenol 3-pentadecyl- Diisooctyl phthalate, 2H-1-Benzopyran-6-ol, Phenol 2-methyl-Diisooctyl phthalate, Gamma-Tocopherol, Vitamin E, Stigmast-4-en-3-one and Lup-20(29)-en-3-one; (
[Table 3](javascript:;)), even though they occurred in different percentage proportions in the extracts.[ [135](javascript:;)] The study suggested possible therapeutic properties of the identified compounds.
Extracts (aqueous, ethanolic and methanolic) obtained from the fleshy part of S. mombin fruit were analysed for total phenols and flavonoids, antioxidant capacity and hemolysis inhibition in human blood assays, with claims that the fruits are a good source of antioxidants.[
[179](javascript:;)] The report indicated that aqueous extract possessed the greatest efficacy of conferring protection on the human erythrocytes studied, while the ethanolic extract demonstrated a good source of phenolic and flavonoid content.[ [179](javascript:;)] Bioactive components of the extracts to which the antioxidant capacity was attributed were a total of 23 including gallic acid, and resorcinol. Others included chlorogenic acid, catechin and ellagic acid. Owing to the richness of the leaf, root, and stem bark of S. mombin in alkaloids, cardiac glycosides, flavonoids, saponins, tannins, steroids, the valuable medicinal efficacy of the plant has been highlighted and recommended for drug formulation in pharmaceutical industries.[ [180](javascript:;)]
The preliminary phytochemical screening of the leaf and stem bark extracts of S. mombin, indicated that the leaf contained saponin, alkaloid and tannin. Meanwhile, flavonoids, alkaloids and tannins were detected in the stem bark. In addition, the leaf extract contained more vitamins C and E than the stem bark extracts.[
[181](javascript:;)]
The leaf, bark, and root of S. mombin harvested in Umudike, Nigeria and analysed for their chemical composition revealed bioactive constituents consisting of alkaloids (0.36–0.78 mg/100 g), flavonoids (0.16–0.32 mg/100 g), saponins (1.06–3.90 mg/100 g), tannins (0.17–0.36 mg/100 g) and phenols (0.09–0.10 mg/100 g).[
[182](javascript:;)]
Recently, the root bark of S. mombin was reported to have proportions of carbohydrates, reducing sugar, alkaloids, glycosides, saponins, tannins, flavonoids, resins, proteins, steroids, oil and terpenoids in the methanolic extract,[
[183](javascript:;)] while the aqueous and ethanolic extract of the leaf contained tannins, saponins, alkaloids and anthraquinones.[ [183](javascript:;)] These constituents were linked with the antimicrobial properties of the plant against vibrio attack.[ [184](javascript:;)] Furthermore, tannins, flavonoid, coumarins, reducing compounds and anthraquinones were the contituents detected hydro-alcohol extract of S. mombin leaves,[ [185](javascript:;)] while saponins, alkaloids, flavonoids, tannins, oxalate, phytates and cyanogenic glycosides in the proportion of 4.80%, 3.40%, 2.80%, 1.47%, 0.92%, 1.73% and 0.01% respectively were the leaf extract.[ [32](javascript:;)]
Spondias mombin has good amount of phenolic and tannin content.[
[186](javascript:;)] Anthraquinones, berberine, flavonoids and naphthoquinones as well as quassiniods, sesquiterpenes, quinoline alkaloids, and indole were linked to the antimalarial activity of S. mombin.[ [187](javascript:;), [188](javascript:;)] Tannin, saponin and anthraquinone glycosides from S. mombin demonstrated antimicrobial effects, but, with no significant antifungal efficacy.[ [189](javascript:;)] Tannin and saponins were also reported in the leaf of S. mombin,[ [30](javascript:;)] while the compound responsible for the flavour in the leaf was identified as isobutyl-3-hydroxybutanoate[ [148](javascript:;)] ( [Table 3](javascript:;)).
It has been reported that different parts of the plant have varying medicinal properties owing to the richness in alkaloids and saponins, as well as the abundance of flavonoids and tannins in the leaf.[
[38](javascript:;)]
Saponins (4.80 mg/ml), alkaloids (3.40 mg/ml), total flavonoids (2.80 mg/ml), tannins (1.47 mg/ml), steroids (0.92 mg/ml), total phenolics (1.73 mg/ml) and cardiac glycosides (0.01 mg/ml) were reported in a recent phytochemical analysis of ethanolic extract of S. mombin leaves,[
[3](javascript:;)] similar to the reports of tannins (3.80%), alkaloids (5.97%), flavonoid (3.00%), saponins (7.50%), phenols (0.96%) as the phytochemical constituents of S. mombin leaf.[ [190](javascript:;)]
Alkaloids, tannins, flavonoids, phenols, anthraquinone glycosides and saponins were present in the methanolic leaf extract of S. mombin.[
[191](javascript:;)] Preliminary phytochemical analysis showed the presence of tannins, saponins, sterol, glycosides and resins in the aqueous extract of S. mombin leaf.[ [192](javascript:;)] The anti-tumour potential of S. mombin bark was linked to major constituents (alkaloids, saponins, tannins, phenolic compounds and eugenol), as revealed in the phytochemical analysis.[ [193](javascript:;)]
Furthermore, phytochemical screening with ethyl acetate, hexane and methanol fractions revealed alkaloids, tannins, phenols, and flavonoids across board.[
[194](javascript:;)] Cardiac glycosides and carbohydrates were noted in both the ethyl acetate and methanol fractions, whereas steroids were noted for hexane and ethyl acetate fractions.[ [194](javascript:;)] Saponins and tannins were reported to be present in the leaf of S. mombin.[ [100](javascript:;)]
Novelty was reported in the compound yields from the chromatographic separation of immixed n-butanol and ethyl acetate fractions, from S. mombin.[
[195](javascript:;)] Undec-1-ene and quercetin-3-O-β-D-glucopyranoside, which were characterized out of the other compounds indicated that S. mombin is a promising source of chemical agents of various prophylactic and chemotherapeutic advantages.[ [195](javascript:;)] The phytochemical screening from the study identified the predominance of anthraquinones, flavonoids and tannins in the ethyl acetate and n-butanol fractions, while terpenoids and steroids were more prominently constituted in the dichloromethanic fraction.[ [195](javascript:;)]
Lutein, β-cryptoxanthin, α-carotene, β-carotene, gallic acid, catechin, chlorogenic acid, rutin, quercetin, ruteolin, 3-O-methylquercetin, and kaempferol constituted the total phenolic compounds, antioxidants, carotenoids, and polyphenols in S. mombin pulp.[
[42](javascript:;)] The liquid chromatography-mass spectrometric (LC–MS) evaluation of the hydroethanolic fractions of S. mombin leaf, indicated the presence of 22 compounds: the major ones being the hydrolysable tannins, O-glycosylated flavonoids, phenolic acids, and carbohydrates.[ [196](javascript:;)] Evaluation of S. mombin from Brazil using dynamic headspace techniques and high-resolution GC–MS revealed 31 volatile compounds primarily esters (48.76%), alcohols (21.69%), aldehydes (11.61%) and ketones (4.19%).[ [197](javascript:;)] Upon HPLC-UV fingerprint analysis, the hydroethanolic extract of S. mombin leaf revealed polyphenolic compounds, well-identified isoquercitrin and ellagic acid, as well as gas chromatography-based derivatives of flavonoid.[ [198](javascript:;), [199](javascript:;)] The compounds identified were majorly of the ester, alcohol, and fatty acid groups.
Pharmacological properties of S. mombin
All parts of S. mombin tree are ethnopharmacologically important. In vitro reports show its antimicrobial activities such as the synergistic activity of S. mombin extracts against Candida albicans and Staphylococcus, as well as the reproductive-related microflora Candida tropicalis.[
[172](javascript:;), [200](javascript:;), [201](javascript:;)]S. mombin juice (25%, 50%, 100%), in an in vivo analysis in Wistar rats exhibited gastroprotective and ulcer ameliorative activities. Here, ethanol-induced gastric lesions were seen to be significantly modulated (42.42%, 45.09%, and 98.21%).[ [202](javascript:;)] Similarly, S. mombin juice (100%) also modulated the indomethacin-induced gastric lesioning (58.96%).[ [202](javascript:;)] Additionally, S. mombin juice (100%) reduced gastric acidity levels (71.97%).[ [202](javascript:;)] Equally, a 14-day in vivo test also showed that S. mombin juice (100%) depleted the chronic gastric ulceronic region (57.34%).[ [202](javascript:;)] The hydroethanolic leaf extract of S. mombin (100–500 mg/kg) was reported to exhibit in vivo anti-inflammatory activity against the carrageenan-induced peritonitis in mice model.[ [166](javascript:;)] In the same vein, the hydroethanolic extract of S. mombin leaf showed anti-inflammatory capacity in the human neutrophil degranulation assay model.[ [203](javascript:;)]
Crude extracts, fractions, and isolated compounds from S. mombin possess a wide range of pharmacological properties, including abortifacient, uterine stimulant, antiepileptic, memory enhancement, neuroprotective, antioxidant, gastroprotective, anti-inflammatory, antimicrobial, and COX-inhibitory, among others, as comprehensively described in
[Tables 6](javascript:;)– [8](javascript:;). These pharmacological properties of the extracts of the plant can be linked to the chemical constituents described in [Tables 3](javascript:;)– [5](javascript:;). For instance, anti-inflammatory and antioxidant activities of two major phenolic compounds: ellagic acid and chlorogenic acid, as components of the hydro-ethanolic leaf extract of S. mombin.[ [166](javascript:;)]

A high yield of flavonoids: quercetin (2.36 mg/g) and ellagic acid (41.56 mg/g) in the leaf of S. mombin was also reported.[
[220](javascript:;)] α-carotene, lutein, β-carotene, and zeinoxanthin, obtained in a similar study were reported.[ [35](javascript:;)] Anticholinesterase compounds (Botulin, campesterol and phytol) were reported as the bioactive agents in S. mombin leaves.[ [346](javascript:;)] Mombintane I and II (glucose lowering principles), were isolated from the leaves of S. mombin,[ [173](javascript:;)] while epicatechin, stigmasterol phytosterol, and epigallocatechin from ethyl acetate extract of S. mombin stem bark were antioxidative and anti-inflammatory agents.[ [57](javascript:;)] Similarly, 3-hydroxy-22-epoxystigmastane and stigmasta-9-en-3,6,7-triol were antimycobacterial agents isolated from the methanolic extract of S. mombin stem bark.[ [171](javascript:;)] Another report showed that 3β-olean-12-en-3-yl (9Z)-hexadec-9-enoate (an α-amylase inhibitor) was isolated from S. mombin leaf.[ [150](javascript:;)] It has also been reported that the isolated members from S. mombin, such as phthalic acid, aspidofractinine-3-methanol, di (2-propylpentyl) ester, 2-ethylhexyl tetradecyl ester, terephthalic acid, and dodecyl 2-ethylhexyl ester 9-(2’,2’-Dimethylpropanoilhydrazono)-3,6-dichloro-2,7-bis-[2(diethylamino)-ethoxy] fluorine, have sole and synergistic activity against Bacillus subtilis, E. coli, and Aspergillus flavus.[ [158](javascript:;)]
Lutein, β-cryptoxanthin, α-carotene, β-carotene, gallic acid, catechin, chlorogenic acid, rutin, quercetin, ruteolin, 3-O-methylquercetin, kaempferol from the pulp of S. mombin were linked to the antioxidant activity.[
[42](javascript:;)] Others being tetradecanoic acid, dodecanoic acid, 4-H-pyran-4-one, n-hexadecanoic acid, and hexadecanoic acid-methyl ester identified in S. mombin seeds were attributed to the antioxidant capacity.[ [152](javascript:;)] In addition, diterpene phytol characterized as the main component in the leaf has displayed interesting anti-inflammatory and antinociceptive activities.[ [140](javascript:;)]
Furthermore, the phytochemical constituents in S. mombin possess several pharmaco- biochemical actions in animals, upon ingestion. For instance, the antifertility activity of the ethanolic extract of S. mombin leaf were attributed to the presence of phenolics, flavonoids, alkaloids, and saponins.[
[3](javascript:;)]
Moreover, these phytochemicals have their individual attributes; saponins are prominent anti-nutritive factors that deplete nutrient uptake, as well as glucose and cholesterol in the gut.[
[33](javascript:;)] This mechanism occurs via the intraluminal and physicochemical interaction, which possibly accounts for the antidiabetic efficacy and serum lipid-lowering capacity of the leaves and fruit extracts of S. mombin.[ [33](javascript:;), [347](javascript:;)] The antimicrobial effects of S. mombin is associated with the presence of flavonoids, alkaloids and tannins while the smooth muscle relaxing activity may also be associated with saponins (steroidals) and alkaloids (ergots), which equally induce the muscular activity of the uterine.[ [348](javascript:;)] Alkaloids inhibit certain mammalian enzymatic activities and usually have effects on glucagon, thyroid stimulating hormone that may in turn cause relaxation of the smooth muscles.[ [348](javascript:;)] Phytochemicals have been reported to be linked with the abortifacient and oxytocic bioactivity of S. mombin leaf.[ [33](javascript:;), [349](javascript:;)] The flavonoids and derivative phenols in S. mombin leaf can be linked to the antioxidant, anti-aging, and anti-herpetic properties. It was concluded in a study that phenolics, saponins, steroids, alkaloids, tannins, cardiac glycosides, flavonoids in S. mombin leaf were responsible for the inducement of male guinea pig infertility.[ [3](javascript:;)] This occurs via biomechanisms such as anti-androgenic activity, endocrinal dysregulation, testicular dysfunction, anti-spermatogenic activity, seminiferous tubular degeneration, and antioxidant activity.[ [3](javascript:;)] Overall, the presence of these array of phytochemicals in S. mombin may account for the narratives on the pharmacological activities highlighted in this review.
Toxicology and safety evaluation of Spondias mombin
Toxicity studies of S. mombin plant on experimental animals including mice, rats and even Drosophila melanogaster are in open literatures. The effect of S. mombin leaf meal on broiler finisher birds’ blood indices was investigated, and found that S. mombin leaf meal was non-toxic, and is thus, 15% incorporable into broiler finisher ration, without deleterious effect.[
[31](javascript:;)]
S. mombin leaf was reported to be safe in experimental animals, upon oral administration (up to 5 g/kg animal weight).[
[281](javascript:;)] Meanwhile, toxicity was observed in animals injected with a leaf extract between 1.36 and 1.86 gm/kg.[ [99](javascript:;), [281](javascript:;)]
The orally administered aqueous leaf extract (200, 400, 800, and 1600 mg/kg body weight) exhibited potential to induce germ line and somatic genetic damage, but no toxicity was recorded by the hydro-methanolic extract administered (50, 100, 200 and 400 mg/kg body weight).[
[246](javascript:;)]
Mitodepression efficacy on cell division and chromosomal aberrations were noted by the effect of 0.5–10 mg/ml of the aqueous leaf extract on Allium cepa.[
[192](javascript:;)] Another study reported conclusively that the use of the leaf is relatively safe but may cause hepatic and renal toxicity upon prolonged use, after the toxicity study of the ethanolic leaf extract at dosage 250 and 500mg/kg body weight on rats.[ [321](javascript:;)]
The exhibited nephroprotective, hepato-protective and genoprotective properties from amelioration of genotoxicity, normocytic hypochromic anaemia, kidney, and perilobular hepatic damage, following oral administration of the ethyl acetate and methanolic leaf fraction (100 mg/kg body weight), in rats have also been reported.[
[194](javascript:;)]
Similarly, the orally administered ethanolic leaf extract (100, 200 and 300 mg/kg body weight) was said to possess a remarkable ameliorative effect in albino rats induced into toxicity by sodium arsenite.[
[350](javascript:;)] Preliminary acute toxicity studies on the aqueous leaf extract of S. mombin, collected in Ghana (at 3000 and 5000 mg/kg body weight) in rats revealed no lethality. In addition, the sub-acute toxicity studies showed no significant physical, physiological, and behavioural effects, and there was no pathological difference in the target organ.[ [303](javascript:;)]
The isolated compound from the ethyl acetate extract of the stem bark was said to have the capacity to reduce the effect of free radicals on the kidney and liver cells, during metabolic activity.[
[171](javascript:;)] The comparative effects of the leaf extract of S. mombin on kidney function profile of rabbits elucidate the safety and widespread use of aqueous plant extracts for a number of diseases, even among expectant and nursing mothers.[ [351](javascript:;)]
Furthermore, no signs of toxicity following administration of 500, 1000, 2000, 4000 and 5000 mg/kg body weight of the S. mombin leaf extract in rats were observed.[
[331](javascript:;)] In another study, it was reported that pre-coital treatment with aqueous leaf extract of S. mombin to rabbits, at dosages as high as 800 mg/kg, favours fertility and did not exhibit any harmful side effects.[ [237](javascript:;)] The juice administered to rats at 15%, 50%, 80% and 100% was found to be non-toxic, even at 100% concentration level.[ [22](javascript:;)]
Some studies have revealed normal morphology of uterine horns, ovaries, uterine body and oviduct-influenced folliculogenesis, with no pathological defects on the reproductive tract of rabbits.[
[323](javascript:;)] In the same vein, research has demonstrated that intraperitoneal administration (750 mg/kg body weight) of ethanolic leaf extract of S. mombin did not have detrimental toxicological effects on the functional indices of tissues or organs.[ [319](javascript:;)] Meanwhile, acute toxicity studies on the extract showed the lethal dose to be indeterminate, while the effective abortifacient dose was 753.96 mg/kg body weight.
On the contrary, the results from the study on feed supplementation of the hydroethanolic leaf extract at various concentrations on D. melanogaster indicated harmful and adverse effects, considering the non-recommended use of S. mombin extracts for the treatment or management of diseases.[
[326](javascript:;)] The doses 250, 500 and 1000mg/kg body weight of the aqueous leaf extract of the plant harvested in Côte d’Ivoire were reported to be toxic to the liver and kidney of experimental rats, when intake was prolonged.[ [325](javascript:;)]
It has been stated that the use of stem bark extracts of S. mombin must be taken with caution to prevent hepatic and renal injury.[
[324](javascript:;)] However, the use of the stem bark extracts was reported to be relatively safe in another study following the administration of aqueous, ethanol and ethyl acetate extracts at dosages 200 mg/kg and 500 mg/kg body weight to experimental rats.[ [352](javascript:;)] Research findings have suggested that the administration of methanolic and ethanolic extracts of S. mombin leaf, co-administered with chemical related substance for therapeutic intentions, should be based on strict recommendations.[ [320](javascript:;)]
Due to a limited availability of degenerative disease drugs, the urgency for more natural, non-toxic candidates such as S. mombin is even more palpable.[
[353](javascript:;)] Bioactive capacities including cytotoxicity have been deduced to synergistically relate to the diverse phenolic and flavonoid compounds in S. mombin. [ [353](javascript:;)] Consequently, it has been opined that an increasing global demand for such non-toxic, natural origin drugs will also require an attendant dosage-regulation, to ensure drug efficiency. [ [353](javascript:;)]
Limitations of the Study
This review provides a thorough and exhaustive narrative on the nutritive and ethnomedicinal values, phytochemistry and various pharmacological frontiers, as well as the biosafety evaluation of S. mombin. There however, may be possibilities that the search did not identify few published research works of other languages that cover the scope of the review since the major language for the literature search was in English language.
Conclusion and Perspectives
Spondias mombin is widely distributed in tropical regions across the globe including Africa. The leaf, fruit, stem bark, seed, pulp, root, and flower are useful for the management and treatment of maladies like leprosy, severe cough, diarrhoea, dysentery, dyspepsia, gastralgia, colic, constipation, hemorrhoids, gonorrhea, leucorrhoea, dystocia, postpartum haemorrhage, diabetes, malaria, depression, ulcer, and inflammation. Various chemical constituents of phenols, tannins, anthraquinones, flavonoids, 6-alkenylsalcyclic acids, caffeoyl ester, alkaloids, saponins, and proanthocyanins, have been isolated from S. mombin, most of which are linked to the bioactivities of the extracts. Overall, S. mombin has a wide range of nutritional benefits and ethnomedicinal uses owing to the chemical constituents in the plant that can be linked the several pharmacological activities and should be taken with dosage caution, upon the advice of medical professionals.
Future studies are encouraged with attentions on the mechanism of biological activities and structure-function relationships of bioactive constituents from the extracts and fraction of S. mombin plant. In this regard, the advent of modern instrumentation analytics of the NMR spectroscopy order, thus become more significant, considering the development of its excellent visual spacing signalling spectra.
Furthermore, the active constituents should be made to pass through clinical trials and formulated to widely accepted drugs that can be safe to use in combatting different ailments and diseases suggested in the folkloric usage.
